posts.author: VonMord
posts.content:
I'm working with the vanilla rules.  Not playing (yet) on any PWs.  

The idea behind the character is to be pretty good at everything: melee combat, spells, and certain rogue skills, so that the character is self-sufficient in any situation.

To achieve that I have been working with the Druid Rogue Monk combo.  Druid for the spells, animal and elemental forms, and ultimately dragon shape.  Monk to make those forms uber killy and for all the monk cheese.  And Rogue to handle traps, locks, and UMD.  

I've been playing around with a few variants:
Druid 32, Monk 5, Rogue 3 - more Druid levels for SP, animal companion, dragon breath, spells duration, one more bonus feat, +1 monk AC, but the con is sparse Rogue levels which could mean there would be levels where I am behind in what I need for open locks, traps, etc.
Druid 32, Monk 3, Rogue 5 - losing 1 AC from Monk, but gaining more flexibility in applying rogue skills through the levels.  It would be more fun getting this up to level 40.  It also has +1d6 sneak damage for what it's worth.
Druid 28, Monk 6, Rogue 6 - this version loses Druid levels, which give a lot of small perks. It keeps +1 AC from Monk lvl 5, and it has the flexibility of applying the rogue skills more often.

Any thoughts/feedback on the above are greatly appreciated.  

Cheers!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Rogue is also good for one other thing, he protects your dexterity ac from collapsing when you get caught flat-footed.

A buffed dragon-shape can have as much as 48 dexterity so that's 14 ac that you won't lose in that case.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Hello VonMord!
That combination of classes has potential, but is limited to LN alignment. It is hard, or maybe impossible to make a character that literally is good at everything. But that doesn't rule out some degree of versatility that you can find in many good builds.
It will be easier for us to give constructive feedback if you can show us the actual builds and explain what you want to achieve and how you want to play them.

posts.author: VonMord
posts.content:
A few thoughts on this one.  

I'm not sure about zen archery.  I don't think I will use ranged attacks that much given the melee power of the druid shapes.  However, there seem to be no decent feats to take pre-epic.

Disable trap allows disarming DC 36 traps.  Epic traps would require another ~20 points, which is a big investment.  

Search will allow detection of epic traps at a little over 50% chance eventually.  It should not take long to spot them.  

Few points in lore combined with a ring of insight will allow to ID cheaper items.  The better items can wait for a store visit.

I'm not sure if 21 points in open locks is enough.  Combined with DEX from some shapes, I can probably open DC 50 locks.  I have no experience if that is enough.  

Since druid has camouflage spells to boost hide skill, hide intentionally lags behind move silently.  

After all is said and done, I think I will use this toon mainly as a buffed melee fighter.   Hence, no concentration.  

In all honesty, hide and move silently are more of a fun factor here than anything else.  You can sneak into a good position and to scout things out, but there is no other benefit really.  You can easily free those skills up for something more useful (more open lock, concentration, more disable trap, more search).  Thinking about it, this may be a more useful way to go.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi VonMord,

I'm not qualified to speak on Druids (don't have the certification), but I've a couple of other thoughts that might work...

If you lose Extra Stunning Attacks and Zen Archery (though I can see some appeal to it), you could take Weapon Focus in Unarmed  and bring Toughness into pre-epic levels, and you could then take Epic Weapon Focus in Unarmed as well. Of course, it only really works if your dragon shape's attacks count as unarmed, which they may well not.

Another thought for pre-epic might be Improved Knockdown (iirc, it's INT governed, not DEX).

As I say, though, I don't know druid stuff...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I'm not a dragon shape specialist either, but i think the WF unarmed feats are bugged. Not sure to what extent you can work with traps and locks when shifted, since several things are limited in that state.
That being said, the build looks good as is. And your thoughts on skill- and feat tweaks seem sound. UMD 40 might be overkill unless you play very high magic mods.

posts.author: VonMord
posts.content:
Thanks for more feedback.  

Extra stunning attacks: I like the stunning attack.  It synergizes well with the build.  With very few monk levels, this feat gives quite a bang for the buck.  

Improved knockdown: since many of the shapeshifted forms are already large or even huge, not sure if that feat works correctly.  Does anyone have any knowledge of/experience with that?

Weapon focus/weapon specialization: according to many sources, those don't work with unarmed shapeshifted forms.  

Now, onto the modified build:

Zen Archery/Toughness - I got rid of the Zen Archery and moved Toughness to pre-epic.  It 

With the freed up epic feat, I added Epic Skill Focus: Disable Traps.  That way I can recover epic traps at CLVL 34 and that's my last level when I take rogue.   

UMD - reduced to 35 to use all the scrolls eventually with 100% success chance.

Removed stealth skills thus freeing up a lot of skill points.  I beefed up disable trap, search and open locks, added 5 points to Set Trap for the +2 synergy.

After all was said and done I had 30 some skill points left.  I decided to fill out lore.  

Now the only decision is whether to keep lore or go with concentration.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: 34 WIS and No ESF: Conuration? Learn to Love SToneHold, it is THE spell for Druids.

posts.author: VonMord
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: 34 WIS and No ESF: Conuration? Learn to Love SToneHold, it is THE spell for Druids.
I could potentially drop toughness and two greater wisdoms for that.  Net gain will be +5 DC on conjuration spells.  

The cost is two less spells (lvl 4 and 8), -40 HPs, -1 DC on all other spells, -1 AC, -1 DC for stunning fist.  

Also, there is no concentration skill for casting in combat but I could get rid of lore for that.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yeah those changes are good VonMord, and i think it is worth it overall. Druids can be very good casters if made for this.

I have somewhere here build that i did for a Druid - not the one in the 40's section - which focusses in Necromancy & Conjuration while attaining DS as well. I have played this one personally in WoG, got him to lvl 38-39 i think, he was Devastating in all aspects. People don't expect to see caster Druids often, but guess what, Slay living & Finger of death had amazing results with high DC's for them. Now add Stonehold's AoE paralysis and also Storm of Vengeance for Conjuration school and he was quite the Caster. And there is also Harm too.. Whatever survived Caster mode, fell prey to Dragon mode and vice-versa..
